sentence.text: De novo heterozygous mutations in protein localization to plasma membrane/Munc18-1 cause early infantile epileptic encephalopathies (EIEE4, OMIM #612164) characterized by infantile epilepsy, developmental delay, intellectual disability, and can include autistic features.

We characterized the cellular deficits for an allelic series of seven protein localization to plasma membrane mutations and developed four mouse models that recapitulate the abnormal EEG activity and cognitive aspects of human STXBP1-encephalopathy.

Together, these cellular studies suggest that impaired protein stability and protein localization to plasma membrane haploinsufficiency explain STXBP1-encephalopathy and that, therefore, protein localization to plasma membrane+/- apoptotic process provide a valid mouse model.

Simultaneous video and EEG recordings revealed that protein localization to plasma membrane+/- apoptotic process with different genomic backgrounds recapitulate the seizure/spasm phenotype observed in humans, characterized by myoclonic jerks and spike-wave discharges that were suppressed by the antiepileptic drug levetiracetam.
protein localization to plasma membrane+/- apoptotic process showed impaired cognitive performance, hyperactivity and anxiety-like behaviour, without altered social behaviour.

Taken together, these data demonstrate the construct, interstrand cross-link repair and predictive validity of protein localization to plasma membrane+/- apoptotic process and point to protein instability, haploinsufficiency and imbalanced excitation in neocortex, as the underlying mechanism of protein localization to plasma membrane-encephalopathy.
